text: So in the work I do, and even back when I was a VP marketing, if we're going to fix this thing, we can't just have the marketing department or just the product managers sit down and cook up new positioning and then heave it over the wall to everybody else, it actually needs to be a group effort. It's a team sport.
speaker: April Dunford
context: Lenny asks about who should care about positioning beyond just founders. April explains that weak positioning often comes from misalignment across different departments - where founders, marketing, sales, and product teams all have slightly different understandings of the company's positioning. She emphasizes that positioning cannot be developed in isolation by one department and then imposed on others.
text_ko: 제가 하는 일에서도, 그리고 마케팅 부사장(VP Marketing)이었을 때도 그랬어요. 이걸 고치려면 마케팅 부서나 제품 매니저들만 따로 앉아서 새로운 포지셔닝(positioning)을 짜 놓고 다른 사람들에게 떠넘기는 식으로는 안 돼요. 실제로는 모두가 함께 힘을 합쳐야 해요. 팀 스포츠(team sport)예요.
text_zh: 所以在我现在做的工作中，包括我之前当营销副总的时候，如果我们要解决这个问题，不能只是营销部门或者产品经理坐下来自己琢磨新的定位(positioning)，然后直接丢给其他人，这事儿必须得大家一起来。这是个团队合作的活儿。
text_es: Entonces en el trabajo que hago, e incluso cuando era VP de marketing, si vamos a arreglar esto, no podemos simplemente que el departamento de marketing o solo los product managers se sienten a cocinar un nuevo posicionamiento y después se lo aviente a todos los demás por encima del muro, en realidad tiene que ser un esfuerzo de grupo. Es un deporte de equipo.

text: When it's working really well, it feels like magic and really great positioning feels obvious. You pitch it to people and they're like, 'Well, of course that's it. What else could it be?' One of my favorite companies, this is a company I worked with a little bit a couple of years ago is Postman.
speaker: April Dunford
context: Lenny asks what it looks like when you've nailed positioning and are in a good place with it. April explains that excellent positioning should feel natural and self-evident to customers. She uses Postman as an example - they have an API platform for building and using APIs, which sounds simple and obvious now, but wasn't always described that clearly.
text_ko: 정말 잘 작동할 때는 마법 같아요. 훌륭한 포지셔닝(positioning)은 너무 당연해 보이죠. 사람들한테 그걸 피치(pitch)하면 “당연히 그거지, 다른 게 뭐가 있겠어?”라고 반응해요. 제가 좋아하는 회사 중 하나고, 몇 년 전에 잠깐 같이 일한 회사가 Postman이에요.
text_zh: 当它运作得特别好的时候，感觉就像变魔术一样，真正好的定位(positioning)就是让人觉得理所当然。你跟别人一说，他们马上就会想"对啊，就应该是这样啊，不然还能是什么呢？" 我特别喜欢的一家公司——几年前我跟他们合作过一段时间——就是Postman。
text_es: Cuando funciona muy bien, se siente como magia y un posicionamiento realmente bueno parece obvio. Se lo presentas a la gente y te dicen: "Pues claro, eso es. ¿Qué otra cosa podría ser?" Una de mis empresas favoritas, una compañía con la que trabajé un poco hace un par de años, es Postman.

text: But particularly, I've worked a lot with companies doing deep AI stuff, deep, deep digital analytics and deep data stuff and you can't tell from looking at the website, whether it's working or not. The true test of whether the positioning's working or not is, if I'm sitting across from a qualified prospect and I tell the story, does the prospect get excited and want to buy something? That's the real test of it.
speaker: April Dunford
context: Lenny asks for examples of good positioning statements and well-positioned companies. April explains that B2B tech positioning cannot be judged by external observers - what matters is whether it resonates with the actual target buyers. She points out that deeply technical products may seem unclear to outsiders but should be crystal clear to qualified prospects.
text_ko: 특히 저는 딥 AI(Deep AI), 정말 심도 깊은 디지털 애널리틱스(digital analytics)나 딥 데이터(deep data) 관련 일을 하는 회사들과 많이 일해 왔어요. 그런데 웹사이트만 보고는 그게 실제로 잘 작동하는지 알 수가 없어요. 포지셔닝(positioning)이 잘 먹히는지의 진짜 시험은, 자격을 갖춘 잠재고객(qualified prospect)과 마주 앉아 스토리를 들려줬을 때 그 사람이 흥분해서 구매하고 싶어 하느냐는 거예요. 그게 진짜 시험이에요.
text_zh: 特别是我跟很多做深度AI、深度数字分析和深度数据处理的公司合作过，光看网站你根本看不出来定位到底行不行。真正检验定位是否有效的标准是什么呢？就是当我坐在一个合格的潜在客户面前，给他讲我们的故事时，这个客户会不会激动起来，会不会想要买我们的东西？这才是真正的检验标准。
text_es: Pero especialmente, he trabajado mucho with empresas que hacen cosas muy profundas de IA, análisis digitales súper complejos y temas de big data muy avanzados, y no puedes saber si está funcionando solo viendo la página web. La verdadera prueba de si el posicionamiento está funcionando es: si estoy sentado frente a un prospecto calificado y le cuento la historia, ¿se emociona el prospecto y quiere comprar algo? Esa es la prueba real.

text: So in B2B, we have two sets of competitors. We have status quo, which is whatever the company is doing to attempt to solve the problem right now, even if it's crappy and not great. And then there's if the company does decide they're going to buy something different, they usually make a short list, so it's whoever else lands on the short list.
speaker: April Dunford
context: Lenny asks about the first step in positioning work. April explains her methodology starts with understanding competitive alternatives - what you need to beat to win deals. She clarifies that B2B companies face two types of competition: the current status quo (existing solutions, even poor ones) and other vendors that make it onto the customer's shortlist when they decide to buy something new.
text_ko: 기업 간 거래(B2B)에서는 경쟁자가 두 종류예요. 하나는 현상 유지(status quo)인데, 지금 회사가 문제를 해결하려고 하고 있는 모든 방식이에요 — 설령 엉망이고 별로여도요. 그리고 회사가 다른 걸 사기로 결정하면 보통 숏리스트(short list)를 만들어요. 그래서 결국 숏리스트에 오른 다른 업체들이 경쟁자가 되는 거예요.
text_zh: 所以在B2B里面，我们面对两种竞争对手。第一种是现状，就是客户公司现在用来解决问题的方法，哪怕这个方法很烂、效果不好。第二种是如果公司真的决定要买新的解决方案，他们通常会列个候选名单，那就是跟我们一起进入候选名单的那些竞争对手。
text_es: Entonces en B2B, tenemos dos tipos de competencia. Está el status quo, que es lo que sea que esté haciendo la empresa ahora mismo para tratar de resolver el problema, aunque sea malo y no funcione bien. Y después está cuando la empresa sí decide que va a comprar algo diferente, que normalmente hacen una lista corta, entonces es quien sea que también quede en esa lista corta.

text: Most folks will discount the status quo, but they shouldn't because in B2B we lose about 40% of our deals to quote-unquote, 'no decision,' which actually means we lost to the spreadsheet, we lost to pen and paper, we lost to interns. And if we're not positioning well against that, we're never going to get the customer to come off of that.
speaker: April Dunford
context: April continues explaining competitive alternatives in positioning work. She emphasizes that companies often underestimate the status quo as competition, but this is a major mistake. In B2B sales, a significant portion of deals are lost not to competitors, but to customers deciding to stick with their current solution, no matter how inadequate it might seem.
text_ko: 대부분 사람들은 현상 유지(status quo)를 가볍게 보는데, 그럴 일이 아니에요. B2B(기업 간 거래)에서는 거래의 약 40%를 소위 '결정 없음'(no decision)에 잃거든요. 사실 그건 스프레드시트(spreadsheet), 펜과 종이(pen and paper), 인턴(interns)에게 진 거예요. 그리고 그걸 잘 공략하지 않으면 고객을 거기서 벗어나게 만들 수가 없어요.
text_zh: 大多数人都不把现状当回事，但其实不应该这样，因为在B2B里面，我们大概有40%的单子都败给了所谓的"不做决定"，说白了就是败给了Excel表格，败给了纸笔记录，败给了实习生在用的那些老办法。如果我们不好好地跟这些东西做对比，突出我们的优势，客户永远不会放弃他们现在的做法。
text_es: La mayoría de la gente subestima el status quo, pero no deberían hacerlo porque en B2B perdemos como el 40% de nuestras ventas por lo que llaman "no hay decisión", que en realidad significa que perdimos contra la hoja de cálculo, perdimos contra el lápiz y papel, perdimos contra los becarios. Y si no nos posicionamos bien contra eso, nunca vamos a lograr que el cliente se mueva de ahí.

text: And so we have to be able to give customers that when they get on the sales call with us. The best thing we could do is say, 'Look, buddy, there's lots of CRMs out there, and let me tell you how this market shakes out. These ones are really good for big enterprises. These ones are really good, if you got this. These ones are really good, if you got this. But look, if you're this, this and this, you really need these four things and we got that and that's why you should pick us.'
speaker: April Dunford
context: April describes the B2B buying process where a decision-maker assigns someone (like John) to research and recommend a solution. She explains that this person needs to justify their choice to their boss and cannot just pick randomly. The best positioning helps customers understand how the market is segmented and why your solution is specifically right for their situation.
text_ko: 그래서 고객이 우리와 영업 상담(sales call)을 할 때 그걸 제공할 수 있어야 해요. 가장 좋은 방법은 솔직히 말해서, "보세요, 고객관계관리 시스템(CRM)이 정말 많고 이 시장이 어떻게 정리되는지 제가 설명드릴게요. 어떤 것들은 대기업에 잘 맞고, 어떤 것들은 이런 경우에, 또 어떤 것들은 저런 경우에 더 좋아요. 그런데 만약 고객님이 이런 조건이라면 진짜로 필요한 건 이 네 가지이고, 그걸 저희가 모두 갖추고 있으니 그래서 저희를 선택하셔야 해요."라고 말하는 거예요.
text_zh: 所以我们在跟客户电话销售的时候，必须能够给他们这样的体验。我们能做的最好的事情就是说："兄弟，市面上CRM系统多得是，我来跟你说说这个市场是怎么回事。这些产品特别适合大企业。这些呢，如果你有这种情况的话，特别好用。那些呢，如果你是那种情况，也很不错。但是你看，如果你是这样这样这样的情况，你真正需要的就是这四个功能，而我们正好有，这就是为什么你应该选我们。"
text_es: Y entonces tenemos que poder darles eso a los clientes cuando se suben a la llamada de ventas con nosotros. Lo mejor que podríamos hacer es decirles: 'Mira, amigo, hay un montón de CRMs por ahí, y déjame contarte cómo está el panorama de este mercado. Estos son buenísimos para empresas grandes. Estos otros están padrísimos si tienes esto. Estos funcionan de maravilla si tienes esto otro. Pero oye, si tú eres así, así y así, realmente necesitas estas cuatro cosas y nosotros las tenemos, y por eso nos deberías elegir.'

text: A better way I think is we know internally that it's the tuna fishing net. That's why we built it. That's what it is, but let's just at the beginning, let's put it out there and keep it a little loose and we say, 'It's a net for fish, big fish, all kinds of big fish, any kind of big fish. And then let's just see, let's let the fishermen try it out. Let's see what they pull up.'
speaker: April Dunford
context: April discusses positioning strategy for early-stage companies. She uses a fishing net analogy to explain that while you may have built your product for a specific use case (tuna fishing), it's better to keep positioning somewhat loose initially rather than being overly restrictive. This allows the market to show you unexpected use cases and customer segments that might be even better fits.
vocabulary_highlights: let's see what they pull up
text_ko: 제 생각엔 더 좋은 방법은, 우리 내부적으로는 이게 참치잡이 그물(tuna fishing net)인 걸 이미 알고 있다는 거예요. 그래서 만든 거고요. 본질적으로 그게 맞아요. 근데 처음에는 그냥 밖에 내놓고 조금 느슨하게 시작해요. ‘물고기 잡는 그물이에요. 큰 물고기용이에요, 모든 종류의 큰 물고기—어떤 큰 물고기든요.’ 이렇게 말해두고 어부들한테 한번 써보게 해보고, 뭐가 올라오는지 지켜보자는 거예요.
text_zh: 我觉得更好的做法是这样的：我们内部心里清楚，这就是专门用来捕金枪鱼的网，我们就是为这个目的造的。但是刚开始的时候，我们对外可以说得宽泛一点，就说"这是捕大鱼用的网，什么大鱼都能捕，各种各样的大鱼都行。"然后我们就看看情况，让渔民们试试看，看他们能捞上来什么。
text_es: Creo que una mejor manera es que nosotros sabemos internamente que es una red para pescar atún. Para eso la construimos. Eso es lo que es, pero al principio, vamos a presentarla de manera más abierta y decimos: 'Es una red para peces, peces grandes, todo tipo de peces grandes, cualquier tipo de pez grande.' Y luego vamos a ver, dejemos que los pescadores la prueben. A ver qué pescan.
